name: NPR
text:
The Ryder Cup and the Presidents Cup are postponing their event dates by a year due to the coronavirus pandemic.

This is the first rescheduling of the Ryder Cup since Sept. 11. 
https://t.co/Wruiez9H5N

name: NPR
text:
As a student, Dajae Williams came up with a better way to learn math —  rapping the quadratic formula or order of operations to make it more memorable.

Her love of math took her all the way to NASA.

Listen on #NPRShortWave ⤵️
https://t.co/PSofsFl5vA

name: NPR
text:
Republican Rep. Doug Collins has asked the DOJ to investigate what he calls "the egregious abuse of power" by the district attorney leading the prosecution of the white officers charged in the killing of Rayshard Brooks.
https://t.co/VfvskNeeYx

name: NPR
text:
Serbia is backtracking from plans to reinstate a curfew after demonstrators gathered to protest the coronavirus-prevention measure, some clashing with police and storming the parliament building.
https://t.co/3jlRPwn8EK

name: NPR
text:
The FBI is investigating after a Black man, Vauhxx Booker, says a group of white men beat him and threatened him with a noose at an Indiana state park on July 4.

After he reported the incident, officers did not make arrests, despite videos by witnesses.
https://t.co/0lSHU0DEO5

name: NPR
text:
Atlanta Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms has signed an order mandating the use of face masks in public spaces — the latest test to Gov. Brian Kemp's order barring local governments from setting their own public health policies.
https://t.co/lF6tL8F2l3

name: NPR
text:
A group representing Brazilian journalists says it will file a lawsuit against President Jair Bolsonaro after he took off a protective mask while speaking to reporters about his positive COVID-19 test.
https://t.co/gWKMYR0fc2

name: NPR
text:
A series of task forces by Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders yielded a 110-page policy wish list for Biden — including recommendations that he commit to eliminating carbon pollution from power plants by 2035 and fund universal pre-K.
https://t.co/0zMkgmKoFP

name: NPR
text:
An independent autopsy finds that Andres Guardado was shot 5 times in the back — and died from the gunshot wounds. An LA County sheriff's deputy shot and killed him on June 18.

"Our son did not deserve to die this way," his family says. "We want answers."
https://t.co/MkYiJLfxhj

name: NPR
text: Despite the pandemic, Census Bureau officials say door knockers will start making in-person visits to households that have not yet filled out a 2020 census form in parts of Connecticut, Indiana, Kansas, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Washington. https://t.co/bMsdqYoW1T

name: NPR
text:
The Ivy League has put all sports on hold until at least January due to the pandemic — becoming the first Division I conference to cancel fall football plans. 
https://t.co/T01piQfyzk

name: NPR
text: Charlie Kaufman's doorstopper new novel could only have been written by Charlie Kaufman — which may seem vague, but it fits the unapologetic, overstuffed "Antkind" perfectly. https://t.co/m9Cyxt9XEd

name: NPR
text:
Black-owned banks in the U.S. control less than 1% of the nation's banking assets.

Author @MehrsaBaradaran says generations of exploitation and exclusion have resulted in a financial system geared toward serving white communities.
https://t.co/8tTYB8p9S7

name: NPR
text: A Trump administration move to force some international students out of the country would jeopardize their dreams -- and hurt the economy. "They brought $45 billion to the U.S. economy and supported over 450,000 jobs in 2018," @tmuguwe writes for @WBUR. https://t.co/PXI4avbzxY

name: NPR
text:
In the meticulously choreographed "John Wick: Chapter 3 – Parabellum," Wick is on the run from foes and former friends alike. 

Halle Berry shows up, Angelica Huston shows up, and, yes, there's still a dog. https://t.co/9NxHjuMFDU
